item.title: Comment on The Generalist interviews me by Anonymous
item.description:
> Their whole strategy of buying cheap energy from Russia to sell to China was a huge blunder. [...] They also have no military whatsoever.
These sound like reasons for Americans be unhappy with German politics, not for Germans to be unhappy with German politics. Selling to China work out great for 25 years. Losing a cash cow may be painful, but that doesn't mean you'd be better off never having the cow to begin with.

item.title: Comment on The Generalist interviews me by M
item.description:
Reply to Anonymous:

> Their whole strategy of buying cheap energy from Russia to sell to China was a huge blunder. [...] They also have no military whatsoever.
These sound like reasons for Americans be unhappy with German politics, not for Germans to be unhappy with German politics. Selling to China work out great for 25 years. Losing a cash cow may be painful, but that doesn't mean you'd be better off never having the cow to begin with.

I think that comment seems to have some bits you could push back at.

Is Germany truly more committed to bilateral trade with China than the United States is? To the degree the US has ended "
Chimerica", it has mainly started engaging in an expensive programme of tariffs and subsidies to practice import substitution, that will increase its deficits. May not be sustainable.

OECD estimates that productivity for Germany relative to the US in 2022 was 99% of the US level and that real PPP GDP productivity growth per hour worked was actually the same for 2023 for US, UK, Germany (Figure 3. Labour productivity growth in 2023, experimental estimate), with Germany performing more strongly than the rest of the Eurozone (Spain, France, Italy, Austria, Netherlands). The "Germany is finished" horse has bolted out of the pen, but can it really get far without getting tired?

Is Germany a warning example of consensus politics? Well, Italy's outcomes show that noisy politics may not work very well either.

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/05/the-generalist-interviews-me.html?commentID=160758980

item.title: Comment on The Generalist interviews me by Shark Lasers
item.description:
Reply to Kinda:

With immigration policy, the executive branch can unilaterally decide how many to let in by loosening its enforcement. Since most aren't filtered in any way, Democrats will have plenty of future voters living on welfare. This "makes sense" as far as the rules of the game are set, but it's extremely anti-democratic.

The problem is that most people are idiots and don't have the processing power to realize that democracy in and of itself is pointless when your overlords are able to manipulate the electorate at will, if not the elections themselves.

That's how you can have the propaganda outlets in the media and pseudo-intellectual Outer Party rearguards like Tyler talk about whether democracy is at stake and the midwits in the MR commentariat immediately jump to Orange Man instead of considering whether democracy got taken out behind the woodshed a few decades ago when our overlords decided to elect a new people.

This is why democracy itself was a bad idea. Most people are not fit to manage their own affairs, much less make sound decisions on the future of a country with an eleventy-trillion dollar budget and hundreds of millions of residents. It would be fine if we were entirely composed of people with a homogeneous background and a common vision, but we're not, thus we are led by sociopaths who hate us.

item.title: Comment on Saturday assorted links by M
item.description:
#6: Oddly in the paper the high-meat, high "beverages" (non-alcholic) dietary subgroup (subtype 3) tended to have the highest odds ratio of depression and an anxiety odds ratio that was comparable to the vegetarian group.

As the paper puts it: "Subtype 3, which followed an unhealthy ‘high protein and low fiber dietary pattern’, had lower well-being scores than other subtypes. ... Individuals, such as in subtype 3, who exhibit a higher intake of fatty meat may experience elevated stress levels and a higher risk of mental disorders, as reported in previous studies on the relationship between diet, stress and mental health"

Fit with my feeling that people with a too much meat (pig meat, cow meat, chicken meat) sort of vibe tend to be people who are reliant on stimulation, low self-control, high levels of impatience, and on average maybe have more self-regulation problems.

"Balanced diet", omnivorous, seems to do best (although maybe the healthy diet subgroup improved after controls for genes or something?).

item.title: Comment on Saturday assorted links by steve
item.description:
Reply to Asher:

#6 - does anybody check causality? E.g. if the correlation is much different for people born into groups favoring vegetarian diets? A lot of people who become vegetarian are motivated by pretty stormy personalities - e.g. Tolstoy. Or confront a number of distressing constraints of which vegetarianism is only one - e.g. Gandhi.

Res ipsa loquitur. Passing up bacon to eat carrots has got to indicate something is wrong.

Steve

item.title: Comment on Why Did We Stop Building Beautiful? The Economics and Ideology Behind an Aesthetic Revolution by Old news
item.description:
It’s baffling to me that neither the original author nor any of the (as of now) 44 commenters mention Learning From Las Vegas, written by Denise Scott Brown, Robert Venturi, and Steven Izenour in 1972. The aesthetic and functional impulses behind these transitions are thoroughly explored there and in subsequent work. Many May at least recall the idea of “ducks” vs “decorated sheds”.

Honestly the oversight is pretty exasperating.

Comment URL: https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2024/05/88328.html?commentID=160758756

item.title: Comment on Why Did We Stop Building Beautiful? The Economics and Ideology Behind an Aesthetic Revolution by peri
item.description:
Reply to Old news:

It’s baffling to me that neither the original author nor any of the (as of now) 44 commenters mention Learning From Las Vegas, written by Denise Scott Brown, Robert Venturi, and Steven Izenour in 1972. The aesthetic and functional impulses behind these transitions are thoroughly explored there and in subsequent work. Many May at least recall the idea of “ducks” vs “decorated sheds”.

Honestly the oversight is pretty exasperating.

The idea of perpetrating a permanent joke on the public, seems wearisome to me - see the Guild House and Venturi's pleasure in its ugliness, which is suspiciously like trying to impute interest to a buildinf when you haven't the skill to make it pleasing sans your commentary - like going into a business where, if you ask, can you help me? the proprietor answers jocularly and pointlessly "I don't know, can I?" clearly for the 1000th time. (Please tell me this happens to other people though it may be a burden for women to bear.)

item.title: Comment on Why Did We Stop Building Beautiful? The Economics and Ideology Behind an Aesthetic Revolution by blue jay
item.description:
Reply to Slocum:

"I'd rather feel awe looking out than envy looking in. YMMV."

But for 99% of people, the only view they'll see of a building is from the outside, not the inside. Even for the wealthy, they'll only see the outside view for 99% of buildings. Nor is there anything preventing otherwise traditionally styled buildings from having more expansive windows using modern technology. Lastly, the idea that traditionally styled buildings are meh inside is questionable. Here's a local example.

Also is that a great example of:

a) the need for windows to enhance lighting (no longer req)
b) a building with lots of structure that doesn't generate useful space (bcz the need for large high windows)
c) a building that likely has ridiculous modern heating costs
d) ?? and was kept at a lower temperature for this reason when it was built?? (e.g, heating was more expensive then, and people were used to colder buildings)

e) maybe the most important: a building constructed whent the state didn't already have 3/4 of its revenue committed to social programs that didn't exist then.
